work.p: This phrase from the manuscript appears, slightly revised, in a self-published review of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass that Whitman wrote for the August 29, 1855, issue of the Brooklyn Daily Times. In the review, entitled "Walt Whitman, a Brooklyn Boy," Whitman describes the book's author as "one in whom you will see the singularity which consists in no singularity."

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: A phrase from this manuscript appears, slightly revised, in a review written by Whitman of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The review appeared unsigned in the August 29, 1855, issue of the Brooklyn Daily Times. The date of the manuscript is therefore probably before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: In the present state of
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p: In the present state of Nothing is society & literature nothing is more singular than to be without singularity, and nothing more eccentric than to be entirely sane & without eccentricity
